column3: E. A. Kolganova, A. K. Motovilov, Y. K. Ho
column4: Complex Scaling of the Faddeev Equations
column5:
6 pages, Talk presented at the International Conference "Modern
  Trends in Computational Physics" (July 2000, Dubna, Russia)
column6:
J. Comput. Methods in Sciences and Engineering 2 No. 1s--2s
  (2002), 149--154
column11:
In this work we compare two different approaches to calculation of the
three-body resonances on the basis of Faddeev differential equations. The first
one is the complex scaling approach. The second method is based on an immediate
calculation of resonances as zeros of the three-body scattering matrix
continued to the physical sheet.

column3:
Akos Dobay (1), Pierre-Edouard Sottas (1 and 2), Jacques Dubochet (1)
  and Andrzej Stasiak (1) ((1) Laboratory of Ultrastructural Analysis,
  University of Lausanne, Switzerland (2) Center for Neuromimetic Systems,
  Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, EDFL-DI, Lausanne, Switzerland)
column4: Predicting Optimal Lengths of Random Knots
column11:
In thermally fluctuating long linear polymeric chain in solution, the ends
come from time to time into a direct contact or a close vicinity of each other.
At such an instance, the chain can be regarded as a closed one and thus will
form a knot or rather a virtual knot. Several earlier studies of random
knotting demonstrated that simpler knots show their highest occurrence for
shorter random walks than more complex knots. However up to now there were no
rules that could be used to predict the optimal length of a random walk, i.e.
the length for which a given knot reaches its highest occurrence. Using
numerical simulations, we show here that a power law accurately describes the
relation between the optimal lengths of random walks leading to the formation
of different knots and the previously characterized lengths of ideal knots of
the corresponding type.

column3: Hongchen Fu, Xiaoguang Wang, Chong Li and Jiangong Wang
column4:
su(2) and su(1,1) displaced number states and their nonclassical
  properties
column5: 10 pages, 3 figures
column11:
We study su(2) and su(1,1) displaced number states. Those states are
eigenstates of density-dependent interaction systems of quantized radiation
field with classical current. Those states are intermediate states
interpolating between number and displaced number states. Their photon number
distribution, statistical and squeezing properties are studied in detail. It is
show that these states exhibit strong nonclassical properties.

column3: Esteban Calzetta, Albert Roura, Enric Verdaguer
column4: Stochastic description for open quantum systems
column5:
16 pages, RevTeX, 1 figure (uses epsf.sty). Shortened version.
  Partially rewritten to emphasize those aspects which are new. Some references
  added
column11:
A linear open quantum system consisting of a harmonic oscillator linearly
coupled to an infinite set of independent harmonic oscillators is considered;
these oscillators have a general spectral density function and are initially in
a Gaussian state. Using the influence functional formalism a formal Langevin
equation can be introduced to describe the system's fully quantum properties
even beyond the semiclassical regime. It is shown that the reduced Wigner
function for the system is exactly the formal distribution function resulting
from averaging both over the initial conditions and the stochastic source of
the formal Langevin equation. The master equation for the reduced density
matrix is then obtained in the same way a Fokker-Planck equation can always be
derived from a Langevin equation characterizing a stochastic process. We also
show that a subclass of quantum correlation functions for the system can be
deduced within the stochastic description provided by the Langevin equation. It
is emphasized that when the system is not Markovian more information can be
extracted from the Langevin equation than from the master equation.

column3:
G. S. Agarwal (Physical Research Laboratory, Ahmedabad, India) and S.
  Dutta Gupta (University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad, India)
column4: Giant Radiative Interactions Among Distant Atoms
column5:
4 figures included in the postscript file, to appear in "Current
  trens in Atomic and Molecular Physics", edited by R. Srivastava (Phoenix
  publishing House, New Delhi, India, 2001)
column11:
We examine the feasibility of enhancing the fundamental radiative
interactions between distant atoms. We present general arguments for producing
enhancement. In particular, we show how giant dipole-dipole interaction can be
produced by considering dipoles placed close to micron sized silica spheres.
The giant interaction arises as the whispering gallery modes can resonantly
couple the dipoles.

column3: F. Barra and P. Gaspard
column4: On the level spacing distribution in quantum graphs
column5: 33 pages and 11 figures
column11:
We derive a formula for the level spacing probability distribution in quantum
graphs. We apply it to simple examples and we discuss its relation with
previous work and its possible application in more general cases. Moreover, we
derive an exact and explicit formula for the level spacing distribution of
integrable quantum graphs.

column3: J. Fiurasek, U. Leonhardt, and R. Parentani
column4: Slow-light pulses in moving media
column11:
Slow light in moving media reaches a paradoxical regime when the flow speed
of the medium approaches the group velocity of light. Pulses can penetrate a
region where a counter-propagating flow exceeds the group velocity. When the
counter-flow slows down pulses are reflected.
